Award.AwardTitle: The Molecular Costs of Being Sexually Attractive: a Quantitative Assessment of Carotenoid Limitations for Coloration and Self-Maintenance
Award.AbstractNarration:
For centuries, biologists have been captivated by exaggerated features in animals (i.e. elongated horns in deer, elaborate bird songs). Evolutionary theory predicts that these 'ornaments' are costly to produce and thus serve as reliable indicators of an individual's worth to potential mates or rivals. Despite several decades of research on animal communication, the true intrinsic, molecular costs that go into producing such signals are poorly established.
The investigators will use comparative nutritional, biochemical, immunological, and morphological approaches to investigate the costs of producing a common exaggerated trait in birds: ornate carotenoid-based plumage coloration. In many bird species, the most brightly colored individuals are preferred as mates. Yellow-to-red carotenoid coloration of feathers requires pigments obtained from food (like in tomatoes and corn), but these same pigments are also valuable for self-maintenance (i.e. antioxidant defense, immunomodulation). This potential trade-off in use of carotenoid pigments is optimal for testing how nutrient limitations dually govern the sexual trait expression and health quality of individuals.
The investigators will study carotenoid intake, allocation, and coloration in wild birds growing their colorful feathers as well as in captive birds fed diets varying systematically in carotenoid content. They will use five pairs of closely related bird species (i.e. blackbirds, sparrows, ducks), one of which shows carotenoid coloration and the other of which does not, in order to test predictions about how carotenoids are apportioned under varying acquisitional and utilizational demands.
This research will contribute to valuable bodies of work on antioxidants and health in humans and domestic animals. Results will be published in scientific and layperson (e.g. magazines) forums to foster scientific learning among broader audiences. Undergraduate, minority, and youth scholars within our institutions and communities will be trained in diverse fields. Fieldwork on colorful backyard birds will stimulate collaborations and information sharing with the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of our research was to understand if and how a limited, colorful nutrient in nature (carotenoid pigments, like carotene in carrots or lutein in corn) impacts the development of animals and may be allocated differently among different body tissues and functions in bird species. There have been many studies to date on the antioxidant and health-enhancing roles of carotenoids in many animals, including humans. Moreover, in recent decades evolutionary biologists have shown great interest in the brilliant colors of animals, including yellow/orange/red carotenoid coloration, and what they have evolved to indicate. Surprisingly few investigations have combined these self-maintenance and evolutionary approaches to understand how different animals may be differentially impacted by variation in carotenoid intake.

We undertook several laboratory 'nutritional requirement' experiments, using two closely related duck species - one of which has vibrant, sexually selected carotenoid coloration (mallard, Anas platyrhynchos), while the other lacks carotenoid pigmentation (Northern pintail, Anas acuta) - to identify if, when, and how limitations or elevations in carotenoid consumption affected body coloration, accumulation of carotenoids in various body tissues, and numerous health parameters. We did this in adult males and females of both species, and in developing mallards of both sexes.

We first completed field estimations of dietary carotenoid intake from wild birds of both species and showed considerable variation among individuals, though no major species differences. We found that very young wild mallards consumed fewer carotenoids than those later in development and at adulthood, perhaps indicating the reliance of hatchlings on maternal sources of carotenoids acquired from egg yolk. We used these levels obtained in wild diets to properly calibrate our lab carotenoid repletion and depletion studies.

When carotenoids were elevated in the diet, young mallards experienced short-term elevations in body carotenoid levels, but garnered few long-term health or accumulation (i.e. coloration) benefits of early-life carotenoid supplementation. Instead, we found strong effects in adults of high dietary carotenoid intake on concurrent coloration and self-maintenance parameters. This further promotes the notion that carotenoids are transient nutrients that must be frequently ingested in order to gain current and late-life health benefits.

In our large comparative nutrition experiment, we found that dietary carotenoid manipulations generated predicted differences between males and females of the two species; on the same diet, male mallards (with colorful, sexually attractive bill coloration) circulated higher carotenoid levels than all others. Moreover, pintails failed to show a sex difference in plasma carotenoids, consistent with the notion of a sexually selected carotenoid uptake system in birds.

As it related to self-maintenance, we surprisingly found that mallards only experienced health benefits of increased carotenoid intake. This stands in contrast to the "trade-off" model and to some prior preliminary evidence that our team had acquired in a domesticated pair of finch species (one colorful, one not). In a wild species-pair model, these findings further implicate specialized, co-evolved physiological systems and benefits that accompany sexually selected ornamental coloration.

Ultimately, this work has broad implications for specific, evolved time periods during which and conditions under which carotenoids confer somatic benefits.
